This is a sloppy example but, here goes - put this into Jeskai Saheeli, you are on the draw:
T1 - Play a land, you have no 1 drops - 7 cards in hand
T2 - Play a land, opponent casts a creature, you either counter it or kill it - 6 cards in hand
T3 - Play a land and cast Kefnet, opponent casts a creature on their turn - 5 cards in hand
T4 - Play a land, pass. If opponent attacks you can use Kefnet's ability to draw a card and return a land - at which point you will have 7 cards in hand, and Kefnet can block. If opponent doesn't attack, draw a card on EOT.

I agree, and the bigger reason to not play either card is probably [[Cavern of Souls]]. But it would be cool to see it do work somewhere, it's cool on multiple levels.
Could almost be [[Wasteland]] art.

It's a very weird feeling for me. On the one hand, my reaction is "man, come on WotC, that is PUSHED". But then thinking about it, I wonder if it will see play in any format, ever. Maybe the reality is somewhere in the middle?

Is the sacrifice of readability worth the effect?
To me, yes. For Invocations, masterpieces, whatever, it is a chance to do something really creative, which they did and it really wowed me in a good way - an effect that would have been diluted if they held back. It's *because* they look so different that it had such an effect. For me the effect was positive, for others, not so.

Somebody wrote this on the blog and it sums up my thoughts pretty well:
"People fear what is new and different. In my humble opinion I am happy you all pushed the boundary on them and I think they look incredible. I wouldnt want normal cards to ever look like that, but for this is the exact type of thing Masterpieces should be."
Meanwhile something like 90% of alters paint over the border.

I like that they took chances for the sake of pushed flavor/style. Masterpieces, Invocations, whatever are the opportunities to go all out and try crazy things. I can see the legibility factor being a thing for newer players, but I guess I just don't care.

I seriously think they did a great job. The art, borders, font choices, and layout all go awesomely with the theme of the set and they weren't afraid to think way outside the box to get there. I'm genuinely surprised by people's negative reactions, but art is subjective - this is ignoring bandwagon folks and people having a momentary overreaction to change.
I love the font, can't please everybody.

I think they are awesome. When I saw the first one, before reading anything I was like "wow", out loud. I was expecting to go to Reddit and seeing people flipping out over them - and they are, just not in a good way. I feel bad for Wizards because I think they did a great job.

I seriously think they did a great job. The art, borders, font choices, and layout all go awesomely with the theme of the set and they weren't afraid to think way outside the box to get there.
I'm genuinely surprised by people's negative reactions, but art is subjective - this is ignoring bandwagon folks and people having a momentary overreaction to change.
I like the art, borders, and fonts A LOT, not being sarcastic, downvote if you want.
Not that this card is particularly amazing, but with all the zombies in this set it would be awesome to see Zombie Tribal make it in Standard.
In a way I'm glad these aren't the real walkers we want to see, I'm ok postponing the excitement.
If I had to bet I would say no because it would lean towards parasitic, but it would be cool flavor-wise if it was a thing.
